sect1.title: Impact of Culture, Gender, Race, Age, and Other Aspects of Diversity
sect1.para: Culture informs the psychological processes of both evaluation and treatment. It is an imperative factor that should be considered by the clinician from the diagnostic phase and throughout treatment. The perception of culture usually refers to race or gender. However, culture can be defined around common themes such as age, religion, social standing, education, financial resources, or veterans’ status . Culture is complex and multi-faceted. For example, an individual may define herself as Hispanic, female, veteran, and Catholic. She belongs to multiple cultural groups rather than just one. Multiple cultural identities may play a significant role in an individual’s comprehension, understanding, and presentation of their mental health symptoms, as well as influence the treatment process and outcomes. Mental health professionals are responsible for being knowledgeable and sensitive to cultural considerations and their potential impact on assessment, case conceptualization, and treatment. Cultural competency is especially relevant when providing treatment for trauma-related disorders: while the self-cognition (e. g., “who I am”) of individuals from independent cultures (e. g., the USA or Europe) who experienced trauma is significantly defined by the trauma, it is much less so for individuals who experienced trauma from interdependent cultures (e. g., South America or Southeast Asia) (Maercker & Horn, 2013 .). These findings are both theoretically and clinically significant. Theoretically, the findings highlight how social norms influence the perception of trauma. Clinically, the findings bolster the existing recommendation that mental health professionals strive to be culturally competent (i. e., knowledge, skills, and attitude).

sect2.title: Gender and Age
Racial and Ethnic Minorities
Sexual Minority Adults
sect2.para: Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Queer, Intersex, and Asexual (LGBTQIA+) people living in the USA are more likely to encounter sexual abuse, crime, verbal harassment, and various types of discrimination in comparison to their heterosexual counterparts (Herek, 2009 ; Rothman et al., 2011 ). The higher likelihood likelihood of victimization explains why sexual minorities also have a higher risk for PTSD (Roberts et al., 2010 ). In an extensive study of 34,653 noninstitutionalized adults living in the USA, Roberts et al. ( 2010 ) found that the PTSD prevalence among (self-defined) gay and bisexual men who were exposed to a potentially traumatic event was 13.38% and 9%, respectively, in comparison to 5.03% among heterosexual men with no same-sex attractions or partners. The study also found that PTSD prevalence among lesbian and bisexual women was 18.04% and 25.68%, in contrast to 12.50% among heterosexual women without same-sex attractions (Roberts et al., 2010 ). These differences in rates for gay, lesbian, bisexual, and heterosexual people are consistent with findings reported by earlier studies (Gilman et al., 2001 ; Herek et al., 1999 ).

Transgender individuals are disproportionately impacted both by exposure to trauma and the higher prevalence of PTSD. A study by Reisner et al. (2016) among 412 transgender adults found the mean number of discrimination attributions endorsed was 4.6. The most common reasons for discrimination were gender identity and expression (83%), masculine and feminine appearance (79%), and sexual orientation (68%). In addition, the study found that it is the combination of higher everyday discrimination and more significant reasons for discrimination experiences that were independently correlated with PTSD symptoms.

Mental health professionals should be aware that new patients may be reluctant to disclose their sexual orientation for a variety of reasons reasons . Research found that only a third (33%) of gay, lesbian, and bisexual veterans who used Veterans Health Care Administration (VHA) services were willing to disclose personal information about their sexual orientation (Simpson et al., 2013 ). The study also found that a significant number of the sample avoided using at least one (25%) or two or more (15.4%) VHA services due to fear of stigmatization (Simpson et al., 2013 ).

sect2.title: The Armed Forces
sect2.para: PTSD and other trauma-related disorders have been extensively studied among military service members and veterans returning from war. Violent combat exposure has been associated with severe mental disorders such as posttraumatic stress, depression, substance use, and risk for death by suicide (Boscarino, 2008 ; Prigerson et al., 2002 ). US military Operation Enduring Freedom (OEF) Operation Enduring Freedom (OEF) and Operation Iraqi Freedom (OIF) Operation Iraqi Freedom (OIF) research examining the prevalence of PTSD among service members and veterans post-deployment found a strong positive correlation between participation in battle and PTSD (Ramchand et al., 2010 ).

Studies have also found a positive correlation between trauma and health-related problems among veterans. Specifically, chronic PTSD was associated with heart disease, as well as with an increased risk of developing inflammatory and autoimmune diseases (Boscarino, 2006 , 2008 ). To summarize, while PTSD and trauma-related disorders are extensively studied among service members and veterans, there is still a lot more to learn. Although different studies often produce different or conflicting results, sometimes due to the use of different measures, the sample studied, or the duration of the study (e. g., single or multiple time points), it is evident that service members and veterans are at higher risk for PTSD than the civilian population.
